title: 108_s2852
content: The Act may be cited as the "Special Olympics Sport and Empowerment Act of 2004". Special Olympics celebrates the worth and dignity of individuals with intellectual disabilities, aiming to end their isolation and stigmatization. Through sports training and competition, Special Olympics promotes skill, courage, and joy for 1,500,000 athletes. Special Olympics provides opportunities for 1,500,000 athletes with intellectual disabilities in 26 sports, aiming to expand participation worldwide. It has a positive impact on their quality of life, improving health, confidence, and community integration. Special Olympics also serves as a platform for breaking down barriers and changing attitudes in society. The United States government strongly supports Special Olympics to help athletes with intellectual disabilities overcome prejudice and negative stereotypes. The purposes of this Act include increasing athlete participation, raising public awareness, promoting family involvement in sports, and highlighting the talents of individuals with intellectual disabilities. Additionally, the government aims to promote the extraordinary gifts of individuals with intellectual disabilities. SEC. 3. ASSISTANCE FOR SPECIAL OLYMPICS. The Secretary of Education and the Secretary of State may provide grants, contracts, or agreements to Special Olympics for education and international activities. This includes promoting expansion, increasing participation of individuals with intellectual disabilities, designing education programs, and supporting volunteer programs. The goal is to integrate these programs into classroom instruction and align them with academic content standards. Activities to increase participation of individuals with intellectual disabilities in Special Olympics outside the US and improve awareness of their abilities globally. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can provide grants for onsite health assessments, screenings, education, and referrals in coordination with private healthcare providers. The Secretary of Health and Human Services coordinates with private health care providers, State and local jurisdictions, and authorized programs. Appropriated funds cannot be used for direct treatment but can be used for Special Olympics with non-Federal funds. SEC. 4. APPLICATION AND ANNUAL REPORT. To be eligible for funding from Special Olympics, an application must be submitted with required information on activities and measurable goals. Additionally, an annual report is required to track progress. Special Olympics must submit an annual report detailing progress towards meeting goals in their application to receive funds. Authorization of appropriations for grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements under sections 3(a), 3(b), and 3(c) includes $5,500,000 for fiscal year 2005 with increasing amounts for the following years.
